summary: Biocatalysis has become a crucial part of modern organic synthesis, with enzymes being used for complex molecule synthesis in industries like pharmaceuticals. Recent advances include de novo design and directed evolution, enabling the development of efficient biocatalytic processes under non-physiological conditions.
key_claims: Enzymes are widely used in chemical synthesis, including making acrylamide on a large scale and being added to detergents for over 30 years.
Recent advances like de novo design and directed evolution have expanded the toolkit of available enzymes for complex molecule synthesis.
Biocatalytic processes can now operate under non-physiological conditions such as high temperature, concentration, and solvent tolerance.

_abstract: Biocatalysis has become an important aspect of modern organic synthesis, both in academia and across the chemical and pharmaceutical industries. Its success has been largely due to a rapid expansion of the range of chemical reactions accessible, made possible by advanced tools for enzyme discovery coupled with high-throughput laboratory evolution techniques for biocatalyst optimization. A wide range of tailor-made enzymes with high efficiencies and selectivities can now be produced quickly and on a gram to kilogram scale, with dedicated databases and search tools aimed at making these biocatalysts accessible to a broader scientific community. This Primer discusses the current state-of-the-art methodology in the field, including route design, enzyme discovery, protein engineering and the implementation of biocatalysis in industry.
